owl:Ontology.dc:contributor: Frank Wawrzik, Christoph Grimm (both TU Kaiserslautern), Konstantin Lübeck, Alexander Jung (both University of Tübingen)
owl:Ontology.rdfs:comment: Domain ontology of general hardware terms and their functions and properties.

owl:Class.obo:IAO_0000115: MIPS (Microprocessor without Interlocked Pipelined Stages)[1] is a reduced instruction set computer (RISC) instruction set architecture (ISA)[2]:A-1[3]:19 developed by MIPS Computer Systems, now MIPS Technologies, based in the United States.

An all-flash array (AFA) is a storage infrastructure that contains only flash memory drives instead of spinning-disk drives. All-flash storage is also referred to as a Solid-State Array (SSA). AFAs and SSAs offer speed, performance and agility for your business applications.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: afa
all flash array

owl:Class.obo:IAO_0000115: Buses serve as the interface between PC components. The CPU, Northbridge and Southbridge are the main components attached to the system bus. There's two types of buses-internal and external

In digital logic and computing, a counter is a device which stores (and sometimes displays) the number of times a particular event or process has occurred, often in relationship to a clock. The most common type is a sequential digital logic circuit with an input line called the clock and multiple output lines. The values on the output lines represent a number in the binary or BCD number system. Each pulse applied to the clock input increments or decrements the number in the counter.

Yet current is a physical quantity that can be measured and expressed numerically. The current in a circuit can be determined if the quantity of charge Q passing through a cross section of a wire in a time t can be measured. The current is simply the ratio of the quantity of charge and time.

(pronounced DEE-RAM), is widely used as a computer’s main memory. Each DRAM memory cell is made up of a transistor and a capacitor within an integrated circuit, and a data bit is stored in the capacitor. Since transistors always leak a small amount, the capacitors will slowly discharge, causing information stored in it to drain; hence, DRAM has to be refreshed (given a new electronic charge) every few milliseconds to retain data.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: DRAM
dynamic random access memory

owl:Class.obo:IAO_0000115: function which executes some piece of code or software

owl:Class.rdfs:label: fft

owl:Class.obo:IAO_0000115: Flash storage is a data storage technology based on high-speed, electrically programmable memory. The speed of flash storage is how got its name: It writes data and performs random I/O operations in a flash.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: flash array

owl:Class.obo:IAO_0000115: Flash memory, also known as flash storage, is a type of nonvolatile memory that erases data in units called blocks...
owl:Class.rdfs:label: flash memory

owl:Class.obo:IAO_0000115: 1. Framing and windowing: In this step the audio signal is sliced into overlapping frames and the Hamming-window function is applied to it.

owl:Class.obo:IAO_0000115: A quantity representing the amount of water vapor in the atmosphere or in a gas.

The complete set of all the instructions in machine code that can be recognized and executed by a central processing unit. ‘A Script is an instruction set used to execute operations on a controller device.’
owl:Class.rdfs:label: instruction set

owl:Class.obo:IAO_0000116: TODO: consider using controls/measures instead of has_property

owl:Class.obo:IAO_0000115:
MFCC (Mel Frequency Cepstral Co-efficients) is a kind of feature in audio processing. They are used as an input for a CNN for wakeword/keyword detection. The coefficients aim to represent the phonemes the human voice and language use.
The computation of those features consists of several steps: 1. Framing and windowing: In this step the audio signal is sliced into overlapping frames and the Hamming-window function is applied to it. 2. FFT: In this step the frequency spectrum of all the frames is computed using a fast-fourier transform computation. 3. Magnitude Spectorgram computation: In this step the result of the FFT is post-processed 4. Matrix Multiply: This step applies the Mel filters to the magnitude spectorgram 5. Non-linear transform: In this step a non-linear function (logarithm) is applied to the Mel filtered data. 6. Matrix Multiply: In this step the cepstral coefficients are computed by computing the discrete cosine transform.
4. Matrix Multiply: This step applies the Mel filters to the magnitude spectorgram 6. Matrix Multiply: In this step the cepstral coefficients are computed by computing the discrete cosine transform.
5. Non-linear transform: In this step a non-linear function (logarithm) is applied to the Mel filtered data.
Performance is an abstract class to represent any kind of performance number, e.g. runtime.
the hardware within a computer that executes a program
owl:Class.rdfs:label: cpu
processor

owl:Class.obo:IAO_0000115: RAM (pronounced ramm) is an acronym for random access memory, a type of computer memory that can be accessed randomly; that is, any byte of memory can be accessed without touching the preceding bytes. RAM is found in servers, PCs, tablets, smartphones and other devices, such as printers.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: RAM
random accesss memory

owl:Class.obo:IAO_0000115: ROM stands for read-only memory. It is non-volatile, which means it can retain data even without power. It is used mainly to start or boot up a computer.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: ROM
read only memory

owl:Class.obo:IAO_0000115: (pronounced ES-RAM) is made up of four to six transistors. It keeps data in the memory as long as power is supplied to the system unlike DRAM, which has to be refreshed periodically. As such, SRAM is faster but also more expensive, making DRAM the more prevalent memory in computer systems.
owl:Class.rdfs:label: SRAM
static random access memory

owl:Class.obo:IAO_0000115: the degree or intensity of heat present in a substance or object, especially as expressed according to a comparative scale and shown by a thermometer or perceived by touch.

A timer is a specialized type of clock used for measuring specific time intervals. Timers can be categorized into two main types. A timer which counts upwards from zero for measuring elapsed time is often called a stopwatch, while a device which counts down from a specified time interval is more usually called a timer. A simple example of this type is an hourglass. Working method timers have two main groups: Hardware and Software timers.

Voltage is the pressure from an electrical circuit's power source that pushes charged electrons (current) through a conducting loop, enabling them to do work such as illuminating a light.
In brief, voltage = pressure, and it is measured in volts (V). The term recognizes Italian physicist Alessandro Volta (1745-1827), inventor of the voltaic pile—the forerunner of today's household battery.
